# Arpeggio: 6th in B

An arpeggio is the playing of the tones of a chord in succession rather than simultaneously. When focusing on the 6th interval within the key of B, you're dealing with the notes B, D#, F#, and G#. The 6th interval is the note G# in this context.

## Notes and Intervals
In the key of B major, starting from B, the 6th interval would be the note G#. When playing arpeggios in B major with the emphasis on the 6th note, you will be incorporating the following notes: B (root), D# (major third), F# (perfect fifth), and G# (major sixth).

## Genre and Musical Flavor
Arpeggios using the 6th in B are commonly found in various genres of music, including classical, jazz, and progressive rock. This specific arpeggio adds a sense of tension and color to the overall sound due to the major 6th interval. It creates a rich and slightly melancholic feel when incorporated in melodies or chord progressions.

## Songs
Here are three songs that showcase the arpeggio of the 6th in B:

1. **"Clair de Lune" by Claude Debussy**  
This classical piece features beautiful arpeggios that emphasize the 6th interval in the key of B.

2. **"All the Things You Are" by Jerome Kern**  
A jazz standard that utilizes arpeggios with the 6th note in B, adding sophistication to the chord progression.

3. **"The Dance of Eternity" by Dream Theater**  
In this progressive rock track, the band showcases intricate arpeggios in B, including the 6th interval, demonstrating complexity and musical prowess.

These songs serve as great examples of how the arpeggio of the 6th in B can be utilized across different genres to evoke diverse emotions and musical textures.
